Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Searching for links between protozoan communities and changes in nutrient availability over time in Antarctic Dry Valley soils
Award.AbstractNarration:
Many protozoa have been shown to play a major role in regulating metabolism in bacteria, which is central to nutrient cycling in virtually all ecosystems on Earth. All organisms depend on these cycling processes, and thus protozoa are integral to the continual existence of life on earth. Understanding which species of protozoa play which role in nutrient cycling will result in more accurate environmental models, a greater ability to manipulate microbial communities in bioreactors, an improved understanding of ecosystem engineering, and aid projects aimed at increasing agricultural productivity. Because the ecology of microbial communities is usually highly complex, this project will use soils from the relatively simple ecosystems of the McMurdo Dry Valleys (MDV) in Antarctica to explore the relationship between protozoan communities and nutrient cycling. Dr. Craig Cary at the University of Waikato in Hamilton, New Zealand is accomplished at characterizing microbial communities in Antarctic environments and has access to unique microcosms that will be essential for this project.

Antarctic soil will be incubated in artificial soil microcosms for an extended period of time to capture the dynamics of a community in nature. Changes in protozoan and bacterial community structure will be subsampled and sequenced at prescribed intervals. Soil geochemistry and nutrient concentration will be analyzed to link nutrient availability to community composition. To provide context for the incubation experiment, environmental DNA from diverse locations and a range of soil chemistries will also be target-sequenced. Significance of bacterial and protozoan species correlation will be inferred using multidimensional scaling (MDS). These data will elucidate habitat suitability models for MDV protozoa, clarifying which elements of the community are driven by abiotic or biotic constraints, respectively. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with Royal Society of New Zealand.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ecosystems in ice free regions in Antarctica, like the McMurdo Dry Valleys (MDV) are highly sensitive to climate warming. As most water there is locked up in glaciers, ice sheets and perennial sea ice, the biotic communities have adapted to a dry, cold desert. However, as local warming trends increase, we can expect to see greater melting and thus a greater volume of liquid water to enter the soil environment and affect the microbial communities therein. Ecosystems in MDV soils are extremely reduced in terms of complexity, and are dominated almost exclusively by microbial metazoans (e.g. nematodes, tardigrades, and rotifers). The soils are also home to a diversity of extremotolerant bacteria and protists. Protists are microbial eukaryotes that are not capable of tissue differentiation (the majority are single-celled) and are best known for ciliates, amoeba, flagellates, and some types algae. Studies have explored some of the relationships between the changing environment and the ecology of metazoans and bacteria in the MDV, but have ignored the effects on protists. As protists provide essential services to an ecosystem (e.g. regulating bacterial populations and primary production) we therefore proposed to begin exploring their ecological role and significance in these valleys. For this specific study, and in light of current climate change predictions, we asked whether soil moisture is a significant driver of protist diversity in MDV soils. If so, impending climate warming may seriously alter protistan diversity, in turn influencing the composition and functioning of the system at large.

To address these questions, I collaborated with scientists’ at the University of Waikato, New Zealand during the EAPSI 2014 summer program. DNA extracted from soil samples from previous field seasons was processed using primers that target sequences specific to eukaryotes. Sequencing was performed using the Ion Torrent, a next generation sequencing platform.

As liquid water is scarce in this environment, it is not surprising that we found its presence seems to dictate overall protistan diversity. It appears that Cercozoa (containing many soil flagellates and amoebae) are present in both relatively wet and dry regions of the valleys: they were found in all samples, even those with extremely low water content. However, ciliates seem to be restricted to areas that have higher water content. As our results are only preliminary, it is unclear as to why ciliates are restricted in this way. One explanation may be that ciliates are restricted not by water, but by ecological complexity, as many are predators of smaller ciliates and other protozoa. Thus, if higher water content leads to greater biomass, then we should expect to see predatory ciliates only in regions with higher water content.

Data produced in this study is still being analyzed; in the future we will examine, among other questions, the nature of the ciliates found in the dry and wet regions to discern whether they are bacterivorous, predators of other protists, or something else. Our preliminary results were presented in poster format at the SCAR (Scientific Committee on Antarctic Research) 2014 General Science meetings in Auckland, New Zealand.
